There was no immersion, no isolation, and it was a pain in the ass to play. I'm going to break this re-review down into story, gameplay, and tone, and we'll see where it gets us.

Firstly, the story. BZ's original release had you living comfy in a base on the surface, with your sister pestering you about random crap. After you fall into the ocean during a storm and can't return to your base, your player character goes "Nah don't come rescue me I'm good lol" and you start the game with an ever-present space station orbiting above you and your sister constantly talking to you about needless garbage. In this game, you begin by going AWOL, launching to the planet in secret and crash landing. This is because your sister in this version of the story is dead, and you've come to investigate what happened to her. Already, this is an improvement. You are once again isolated, once again without help. It feels good to have that back, and I enjoy it a lot. Now for some of the issues. In BZ's initial storyline, you were guided to an alien base underwater and got an alien named Alan put in your head. This stays true in the revamped story, at least so far. Here's the issue with this. You now have a specific goal. Make Alan a new body and get him out of your head. While also finding out what happened to your sister, I guess. Maybe I did the events out of order, but nothing's stopping you from putting Alan in your head the SECOND you arrive on the planet. He's not all that hard to find if you just explore a bit, and you don't need any fancy equipment aside from maybe the seaglide. Having a constant voice in your head with a set mission in a game that's supposed to be about isolation and mystery is... A little underwhelming. I don't enjoy it and I wish it wasn't there. Your sister's death is enough of a story hook, I have no idea why the alien-in-my-head plot is still around.

Next, the gameplay. This uses the same engine as Subnautica proper, so it's not all that different. I will say that the game has less pop-in and is all around better optimized, so that's a plus. My issues arise from the land segments. Yes, you get a vehicle to better traverse the land, however not until a decent bit into the story, as the place you find the fragments is pretty far away from where you start. And moving on land is... Clunky. It has never felt good, but thankfully you don't have to do it much in Subnautica. BZ is different, you do it a lot. Another thing I have to critique is the drive for exploration. BZ does give you drive to explore, but giving you an objective the minute you land discourages some of the starting exploration to some degree. It's also just... Dark as hell. Not like, tonally speaking, it's just dark. Nearly every underwater biome is extremely dark and hard to navigate, and it makes it worrying to want to explore more, because you don't have anything protecting you, and you can't see anything around you. I also ran into what I think is a leviathan early on, and unlike the telltale call of a Reaper, I didn't hear a peep from this one, it was just there goofing around in the water about 250 meters from the pod you start in. Having a bunch of dangerous stuff just messing around so close, when every biome feels hard to see in, makes exploring without a vehicle (which I still haven't found) painstaking. There's no "Ah this is the place I need to go when I get a vehicle", that's just the entire ocean.

Finally, the tone. This is really the only place I think BZ does great. The roar of an ice worm constantly surrounding you while you're on the surface, a trail of alien lights guiding you deeper and deeper down, the beautifully crafted aesthetic of each biome... It's done incredibly well. Below Zero, for all its faults, is truly a gorgeous game with an air of mystery that I drank up with ease. My only real issue is that it gets somewhat samey, and the above ground segments are somewhat lacking due to being, well, above ground. Thankfully various caves and abandoned bases do add content, but honestly BZ's insistence on land exploration feels sort of off to me.

In conclusion: Do I think this is a good game? It's hard to say. In its current state? No, not really. I think it's a bit of a mess story-wise, its biomes are way too hard to navigate safely or confidently without a vehicle, which again, I still haven't found, and despite its gorgeous landscapes, I hardly want to go explore any of them because it's all so damned dark. So, do I recommend Subnautica: Below Zero? Have I changed my mind? No, no I have not. In its current state, I don't recommend it. Whether or not they fix their issues is up for debate, and personally I wouldn't put my faith in a game that had to have its entire story overhauled, and still has some of the same issues in said story from before. Wait for the game to be finished, and then check some reviews once it is. Until then, I can't recommend this with a clear conscience.
